cont.entity_a: Tack sharp, remains sharp even at F1.8, very sharp from f1.8, sharp and fast, produces sharper images compared to other Sony lenses.
cont.entity_b: Sharp with great depth, sharp even at maximum aperture.

cont.entity_a: Brighter colors and crisper than other lenses for Sony, colors and microcontrast are typical Zeiss.
Round bokeh, beautifully diffused backgrounds, bokeh is outstanding.
cont.entity_b: Beautiful shallow depth of field, large bokeh.

cont.entity_a: Heavy lens, not suitable for walking around, best used on a tripod.
cont.entity_b: Lightweight but feels cheap due to plastic construction, small and light.
Autofocus not supported on Nikon d5600, requires AF-S lens, requires manual focus on DX cameras without a focusing motor, noisy when focusing.

cont.entity_a: Considered the pinnacle of technology and optical quality, high price tag but justifies the quality.
cont.entity_b: Built like a tank, performs well but poorly made with loose tolerances, plastic build but offers good optical quality for the price.

cont.entity_a: High price tag but justifies the quality.
cont.entity_b: Good price value, especially for portraits and close-up work.

cont.entity_a: Works well with Sony Alpha cameras.
cont.entity_b: Compatible with older Nikon cameras, not with entry-level bodies.

cont.entity_a: Built-in camera stabilization allows handheld use in low light, perfect for handheld low light photography with stabilization.
cont.entity_b: Fast lens with excellent low light capabilities, great for low light situations with crisp, clear images.

cont.entity_a: Ideal for studio headshots, great for portraits, low-light settings, and action shots.
cont.entity_b: Works well for portraits and indoor photography.

cont.entity_a: Requires moving back physically to get wide shots due to 135mm focal length.
Produces brighter colors and sharper images compared to other Sony lenses.
cont.entity_b: Produces beautiful photos despite minor sun flares, produces beautiful photos but tricky to use initially.
